column1: Mr. Horace Dinsmore was quite remarkable for his conversational powers
column3: who had always heretofore found him a most entertaining companion
column4: wondered greatly at his silence on this particular evening. She waited in vain for him to start some topic of conversation
column5: but as he did not seem disposed to do so
column6: she at length made the attempt herself
column7: and tried one subject after another. Finding
column9: that she was answered only in monosyllables
column10: she too grew silent and embarrassed
column11: and heartily wished for the relief of Elsie's presence.She had proposed summoning the child to accompany them as usual
column12: but Mr. Dinsmore replied that she had already had sufficient exercise
column13: and he would prefer having her remain at home.They had walked some distance
column14: and coming to a rustic seat where they had often rested
column15: they sat down. The moon was shining softly down upon them
column16: and all nature seemed hushed and still. For some moments neither of them spoke
column17: but at length Mr. Dinsmore broke the silence.
